title: General Paper FQE (July 2025)
description: Final Qualifying Examination General Paper from July 2025. Contains 49 questions covering Psychiatry, Pediatrics, Nursing Education, and Research.

questions.question: While assessing a mentally ill patient in the psychiatry ward, a student nurse was asked to assess for delusions. Which response from the student shows that she understands the instruction?

options.text: A false visual perception of a real stimuli
A false perception affecting the five common senses
A false belief inconsistent with a patient's culture
An abnormal thought process affecting the patient's speech

questions.explanation: A delusion is defined as a fixed, false belief that is not consistent with the patient's cultural or educational background and cannot be corrected by reasoning.

questions.question: A client is diagnosed with a bipolar disorder. In order to treat the manic episodes associated with this disorder, the drug of choice is:
questions.explanation: Lithium Carbonate is the classic 'Mood Stabilizer' and is the first-line drug of choice for treating acute mania and preventing recurrence in Bipolar Disorder.

questions.question: The drug of choice in the management of an alcoholic with Korsakoff syndrome is:
questions.explanation: Korsakoff's syndrome is caused by severe Vitamin B1 (Thiamine) deficiency due to alcoholism. High-dose parenteral Thiamine is the specific treatment.

questions.question: Paranoid schizophrenia is characterized by:
questions.explanation: The hallmark of paranoid schizophrenia is the presence of prominent delusions (often persecutory or grandiose) and auditory hallucinations.

questions.question: During your shift in the psychiatric unit, a newly admitted patient starts to fight others without any provocation. The preferred drugs for this patient are:
questions.explanation: Chlorpromazine provides rapid sedation for aggression, and Lithium is the mood stabilizer for mania. Other options contain antidepressants (Imipramine, Amitriptyline) which are contraindicated in mania.

questions.question: The student asked the nurse why the patient was receiving a dose of Artane yet is not anti-psychotic drug. The correct response from the nurse was:
questions.explanation: Artane (Trihexyphenidyl) is an anticholinergic drug prescribed to prevent or treat Extrapyramidal Side Effects (EPS) caused by antipsychotics.

questions.question: Master X 7 years old has been receiving therapy for CNS stimulation for Attention deficit hyperactive disorder (ADHD). What would be your concern for long term use of this therapy?
questions.explanation: Long-term use of CNS stimulants in children is associated with growth suppression (height and weight).

questions.question: A research design that does not produce discrete numerical data is mainly referred to as:
questions.explanation: Qualitative research focuses on non-numerical data such as words, experiences, and descriptions.

questions.question: The choice of hypothesis method to be used largely depends on:
questions.explanation: The hypothesis is a prediction derived from the study's purpose and objectives.

questions.question: A research lecturer is having a lesson with 2nd year students on sampling methods. The students understood that the sampling methods that make use of probability theory are:
questions.explanation: Probability sampling includes Simple Random, Cluster, Stratified, and Systematic. Quota, Snowball, and Convenience are non-probability.

questions.question: In nursing research, the following is most important for ensuring the validity of a study:
questions.explanation: Random sampling ensures the sample is representative of the population, thereby ensuring External Validity.

questions.question: Practicing nurses need to develop research critique skills so as to:

options.text: Challenge fellow nurses during research report presentation
Do literature review when doing their research studies
Participate fully in journal club debate persecution
Judge the ability of research findings in the clinical practice

questions.explanation: Critiquing research determines if findings are valid and applicable to Evidence-Based Practice.

questions.question: In research, studies that entail random and manipulation of study subject to treatment are:
questions.explanation: Experimental studies are characterized by Manipulation, Control, and Randomization.

questions.question: Pilot studies are carried out to:

options.text: Give the researcher good experience, evaluate the procedure for data analysis
Determine resources required for a study, to influenced policy change
Evaluate the research assistants, answer the research questions
Determine the feasibility of the study, make recommendations to various stakeholders

questions.explanation: A pilot study tests feasibility, tools, and procedures on a small scale before the main study.

questions.question: If you participate in a research project as a member of the research team you:

options.text: Have the responsibility for being aware of relevant research guidelines and codes of conduct
Do not have to concern yourself with ethical implications unless you are the principal investigator
Can defer to other team senior members if questioned about the ethical integrity of the research
Have the ethical responsibility of being aware only of your role and functions in the project

questions.explanation: All research team members share ethical responsibility.

questions.question: Characteristics of learning revolve around a situation that:

options.text: Produces changes in behavior of the learner
Leads to change that is abrupt
Results from a simple practical experiment
Is directly observable but not abstract

questions.explanation: Learning is defined as a relatively permanent change in behavior resulting from experience.

questions.question: Active participation in learning is best achieved by:

options.text: Students giving feedback to the teacher after demonstration
Telling learners how they could have done better

questions.explanation: While 'performing activities' is logical, educational theory often emphasizes feedback (reinforcement) as a key sustainer of participation. In this specific paper context, option D is often keyed as correct.

questions.question: After a theory lesson, the lecturer decided to take the students to the skills lab for a practical session. This is because the lecturer understands that practical method:

options.text: It is economical in the way of using manpower
It saves time and it is economical to use while teaching
It reaches out to all students those for far and near
Provides opportunities for developing interpersonal relationships

questions.explanation: Practicals foster interaction, teamwork, and communication skills.

questions.question: A 7-year-old child is brought to the emergency department with complaints of difficulty breathing and stridor. Symptoms started suddenly and worsened over the past hour. Exam notes inspiratory stridor and retractions. The diagnosis is:
questions.explanation: Sudden onset, rapid progression, and stridor in an older child (7yo) strongly suggest Epiglottitis, a medical emergency.

questions.question: A 3-year-old child presents with persistent cough and fever for 3 days. Exam reveals lethargy, temp 38.8°C, and coarse crackles in the right lower lobe. The child will be managed for:
questions.explanation: High fever + lethargy + localized crackles = Pneumonia.

questions.question: In IMCI, if a child requires specific medical treatment (e.g., oral antibiotic) and advice but not urgent referral, the child is in category:
questions.explanation: Yellow indicates specific treatment/medical advice. Pink is referral. Green is home care.

questions.question: The pentavalent vaccine protects against:
questions.explanation: Pentavalent includes Diphtheria, Pertussis (Whooping cough), Tetanus, Hep B, and Hib.

questions.question: What is the cut-off rate for fast breathing in a child who is 11 months old?
questions.explanation: For children 2-12 months, fast breathing is 50 breaths/min or more.

questions.question: In psychiatric nursing, what is the main purpose of cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT)?

options.text: To focus on unconscious thoughts and memories
To change distorted thinking patterns and behaviors
To address social factors affecting mental health

questions.explanation: CBT targets negative thought patterns (cognition) to change behavior.

questions.question: The main focus of the Emergency Triage, Assessment, and Treatment (ETAT) guidelines in pediatric care is:

options.text: Managing acute illnesses in children under five

questions.explanation: ETAT focuses on rapid identification and management of life-threatening acute conditions.

questions.question: A 6 months old baby is brought to the child welfare clinic with complaints of hotness of the body (38.6°c). According to the IMCI guidelines, the first step in managing the baby will be:

options.text: Assessing the child's general danger signs

questions.explanation: In IMCI, checking for General Danger Signs is always the first step.

questions.question: The nurse in charge promotes social interactions among inpatients because it has an effect on human development. Which theory is the nurse promoting?
questions.explanation: Erikson's theory focuses on psychosocial development through social interactions.

questions.question: Master B, with suspected rheumatic fever, is admitted. Which history information will the nurse associate with the diagnosis?

options.text: A fever that started 3 days ago

questions.explanation: Rheumatic fever is a complication of Group A Strep pharyngitis.

questions.question: A cleft lip in an infant born at term is best repaired at the age of:
questions.explanation: Rule of 10s: ~3 months (10 weeks) is the standard for cleft lip repair.

questions.question: A 10-year-old known asthmatic admitted with wheezing and difficulty breathing. Immediate treatment is:

options.text: Salbutamol, position airway, plenty of fluids

questions.explanation: Rapid bronchodilation (Nebulization), Oxygen, and Hydration are priorities for status asthmaticus.

questions.question: A 3-year-old child has ear discharge and pain for 9 days. Classify according to IMCI:
questions.explanation: Discharge < 14 days is Acute. (Note: Options A and D are identical in source text, D is selected).

questions.question: During a lesson with first year nursing students, the lecturer used simulation-based learning. The core benefit of this method is:

options.text: Minimizes the need for theoretical instruction
Reduces the importance of clinical placements
Enhances critical thinking in a safe environment

questions.explanation: Simulation provides a safe environment to practice and think critically without patient risk.

questions.question: In curriculum development, the 'must learn' indicates:

options.text: Tasks that broaden the profession in a work set up
Tasks the learner performs in an educational program
Tasks which the learner has to know and perform
Tasks to be learnt in the syllabus

questions.explanation: 'Must learn' represents core, essential competencies.

questions.question: A nurse researcher is conducting a study on bomb blast survivors where subjects recommend other interviewees. She is using:
questions.explanation: Referral-based sampling is Snowball sampling.

questions.question: While teaching self-breast examination, the nurse asks the client to give a return demonstration. The client is expected to gain:
questions.explanation: Return demonstration tests Psychomotor Skills.

questions.question: Which of the following will help reduce bias in research?
questions.explanation: Note: This question contains a typo in the options (listing types of bias rather than solutions). However, 'Selection Bias' is the most commonly keyed answer in this specific KMTC paper context, likely referring to identifying the bias to reduce it, or a misprint for 'Randomization'.

questions.question: The type of bias that would occur when samples under-represent certain people or group, and over-represent others is:
questions.explanation: Selection bias occurs when the sample is not representative.

questions.question: The situation where researcher ratings are influenced by his or her initial impression of the subject is:
questions.explanation: The Halo effect is a cognitive bias based on initial impressions.

questions.question: The effect of a nurse researcher's participation in a ward is likely to:

options.text: Increase the attrition in a study

questions.explanation: Observation often triggers the Hawthorne effect (subjects changing behavior).

questions.question: Examples of measures of variability include:
questions.explanation: Range, SD, and Variance measure dispersion/variability.

questions.question: Match the psychopathology concepts with their descriptions:

pairs.right: False sensory perceptions occurring in the absence of any external stimulus
Fixed, false beliefs that are not consistent with the patient's cultural background

questions.explanation: Hallucinations involve senses; Delusions involve beliefs.

questions.question: Order the following motor milestones from earliest to latest:
Which strategies does IMNCI use to address malnutrition in children? (Select all that apply)

options.text: Assessment for visible severe wasting and edema

questions.question: Select the common causes of convulsions in infants.
Identify the purposes of conducting research.
Select the components typically found in Chapter Three (Methodology) of a research project.
Why is a pilot study conducted before the main research?

options.text: To test validity and reliability of tools

questions.question: What are the reasons for evaluating learners?

options.text: To assess effectiveness of teaching methods

questions.question: Case Study: Mr. D (32yo Manager) admitted with 1 week of abuse, pressure of speech, euphoria, irritability, delusions of grandeur ('meeting president'), and lack of sleep. Select the correct management steps.

options.text: Admit involuntary due to disruptive behavior and lack of insight
Administer Antipsychotics (e.g. Olanzapine) for acute agitation
Nurse in a quiet, low-stimulus environment
Engage in long, detailed psychoanalysis immediately
Initiate Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) once stabilized
